awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Chemical and Dynamic Heterogeneities in Interfaces for Adaptive Polymer Nanocomposites
awd_abstract_narration:
Polymer composites are widely used as lightweight functional materials for a breadth of applications, including sensors, wearable electronics, and biomedical applications. These materials, however, often suffer from low mechanical strength, particularly at elevated temperatures. Soft hybrid materials with high strength under extreme conditions have been developed at small scales, but to scale these materials up to manufacturing capacities, the fundamental mechanisms of controlling the mechanical behavior of these materials must be understood. This award supports fundamental research to uncover the underlying physics and chemistry that control the high mechanical and functional performance of adaptive polymer nanocomposites. The scientific knowledge resulting from this research has the potential to enable a new class of high-performance materials, and the combined experimental and computational approaches build on an educational paradigm that provides opportunities for students participating in the research, training the next generation workforce in advanced engineering techniques.

A driving motivation of this research is to develop mechanically adaptive materials based on the unique dynamic behavior of nanocomposites. The material system of interest consists of miscible polymers with large differences in glass transition temperature (Tg), coupled with a dispersion of nanoparticles. Spherical nanoparticles adsorbed within a high-Tg polymer and dispersed in a low-Tg polymer matrix have been shown to result in a thermally-induced stiffening behavior. In this research program, the investigators examine the role of chemical and dynamic heterogeneities in particle-polymer interfaces of such polymer nanocomposites to understand the mechanical characteristics of adaptivity. Chemical heterogeneities in interfacial polymer layer are studied to explain the reinforcement phenomena in different polymer architectures and with different particle shapes (nanotubes and nanospheres). Conformation of chains, in looped, stretched, and collapsed states, will be explored via molecular dynamic computational simulations to support the experimental results. Computer simulations are designed to run in parallel with experiments to guide experimental work and to inform material design space. More importantly, the influence of various molecular physical parameters such as chain stiffness can be identified by these simulations.  Deformation of polymer nanocomposites under large oscillatory shear will be utilized to reveal the fundamental mechanism of adaptive mechanics in composites. Existing network theories will be used to analyze the non-linear rheological data and the effects of different polymer architectures on particle behavior. The knowledge gained from this project will transform the current knowledge of static properties of nanocomposites to extend to dynamically adaptive polymer hybrids.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF THE STEVENS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
Particle-polymer interphases play an important role in controlling the particle dispersion, hence reinforcement of polymer nanocomposites. In this project, interphases in polymer nanocomposites were investigated with the chemical and dynamic heterogeneities to control the local viscosity, interfacial layer reinforcement, and thermal-stiffening. Using the model linear poly(ethylene oxide) to crosslinked linear poly(methyl acrylate) as matrix chains, the adaptive mechanical properties of composites under varying temperature and deformation protocols have been studied. The complex interfacial mixing in the polymer-adsorbed, polymer-grafted and loop-grafted chains was explored. The central goal of our project was to develop soft hybrid materials that are mechanically adaptive to shear and temperature. This feature enabled the multifunctional material performance in reinforced nanocomposites as they respond to shear and temperature unusually, offering autonomic healing behavior with the absence of any chemical reactions. The composite design strategy relied on the use of miscible polymers with different glass transition temperature, polymer architectures and molecular rigidity on surfaces of spherical fillers. Overall, we showed that chemical and dynamic heterogeneities of interfacial layers between particle?polymer can be used to tune the dynamics of interfacial polymers, hence the mechanical properties such as thermal-stiffening.

Intermixing between chemically different polymers around nanoparticles creates chemically heterogeneous layers, exhibiting unusual dynamic anomalies due to dynamic confinement and coupling phenomena in polymer nanocomposites. Interfacial mixing of chains is possible when adsorbed chains are mobile above their glass transition temperature, leading to enhanced entanglement density at the interphase. Linear rheology data of polymer nanocomposites with chemically heterogeneous interphases around nanoparticles were analyzed over a wide frequency range to investigate the role of chain rigidity on matrix chain relaxations and particle diffusion.

Interphase controlled viscoelastic properties in polymer nanocomposites were found to be regulated with the rigidity of adsorbed chains. When adsorbed chains are less rigid, matrix can easily entangle with adsorbed chains and slow down the interfacial layer dynamics. We reported the slowing down of the matrix chains through the chain entanglements and particle diffusion by analysis of rheology data. Moreover, our findings showed that nanoparticles adsorbed with less rigid polymer moved in sub-diffusive mode. Nanoparticles adsorbed by flexible polymer can slow down the matrix polymer dynamics and particle diffusion, and this interphase effect enhanced viscoelastic properties of the whole polymer nanocomposite.

Understanding particle dynamics and rheological behavior of reinforced systems is essential to develop design rules for gels and real network composites. To understand the influence of particles and entanglements on the rheology of crosslinked networks, poly(methyl acrylate) (PMA) nanocomposites and their crosslinked forms were prepared. PMA-bare SiO2 composites, the unentangled and entangled crosslinked composite networks and the particle-free networks were characterized in linear and nonlinear deformation experiments. We demonstrated that permanent (unentangled) networks were reinforced with particle loading unlike the entangled composite networks. The fast and full recovery of entangled composite networks after large deformation indicated that particles did not influence the entanglements and modulus recovery after large deformation, which revealed the dynamic differences between permanent and entangled composite networks.

In addition, the interfacial layers around magnetic nanoparticles were studied by measuring the local viscosities in composites upon magnetic heating. The changes in local viscosities were attributed to the rigidity of adsorbed polymers and chemical heterogeneities of their interfacial layers. The highest viscosity was measured with the flexible, shorter adsorbed poly(methyl methacrylate) chains. The weak interphases between highly rigid polymers such as poly(2-vinyl pyridine), poly(bisphenol A carbonate), and poly(methyl acrylate) allowed particles to rotate easily in a diffusive mode, yielding the lowest viscosity that matched to the viscosity prediction of an unentangled matrix polymer. Measuring the local viscosity of interfacial polymer layers are important for interfacial layer-controlled mechanisms of stress transfer, reinforcement and thermal conductivity in polymer nanocomposites. The internal heating of magnetic nanocomposites and their interfacial layer-controlled viscosities can be utilized for drug delivery systems and flexible electromagnetic actuator membrane designs. 

The project contributed extensively to the graduate education of 3 PhD students. The outreach component of the project has achieved its ambitious goal by educating science teachers in nanoscience and technology through Nanoscience Educator workshops. The workshop materials and the established modules for the Nanoscale Science and Engineering course for high school is now being used for the Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) program at Stevens.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/25/2022
Modified by: Pinar Akcora
